In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  (SAARC)  summit,  held  in 
Thimphu, Bhutan, in 2010, recognized the importance of developing transport infrastructure and 
transit facilities, especially for landlocked countries, to promote intra-SAARC trade. Recent 
agreements on regional connectivity between Bangladesh and India during 2010 are a critical 
stepping stone for opening connectivity, not only between Bangladesh and India, but also with 
Bhutan and Nepal, diversifying regional and international transport routes to provide the most 
efficient routes. This will enhance markets and opportunities for regional development in South 
Asia, leading to balanced regional growth and poverty reduction. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been supporting regional cooperation in the 
transport sector through SAARC, the Bay of Bengal Initiative for MultiSectoral Technical and 
Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC), and the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation for 
over a decade. Major contributions include assisting the SAARC Regional Multimodal Transport 
Study (SRMTS)1 and the BIMSTEC Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study (BTILS).2 The 
transport sector is a priority for regional cooperation and integration as identified in the second 
High Level Forum on Emerging Vision for Shared Prosperity: South Asia and Beyond, held in 
Manila in August 2010. 
 
3.  The  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)3 is  built  on  the  strategic  directions  and 
understanding established under SRMTS and BTILS, with a focus on the four South Asian 
countries: Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and Nepal; and will identify the economic impacts of 
priority subregional transport projects on the national and regional economies. It will promote 
interregional  and  intraregional  transport  connectivity,  improve  cross-border  transport,  and 
enhance optimal multimodal mix and intermodal connectivity. The fact-finding mission visited 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and Nepal from 23 August to 9 September 2010. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  Although South Asia has been one of the fastest-growing economic regions in the world, 
intraregional trade accounts for only about 5% of total trade in the region. By comparison, 
intraregional trade accounts for 26% of total trade in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, 
52% of total trade in North American Free Trade Agreement countries, and 58% of total trade in 
the European Union. The South Asian Free Trade Area is slowly being implemented, while 
bilateral free-trade agreements have also encouraged an increase in trade volumes. However, 
investment in the region must be accelerated, particularly in less-developed areas. 
 
5.  Road transport accounts for 65%–70% or more of the freight movement in South Asia 
and dominates the overall regional transport system. However, South Asia has one of the 
largest  railway  networks  in  the  world,  with  systems  in  India,  Bangladesh,  and  Sri  Lanka. 
Although it has been losing its market share to road transport, this trend could be reversed by 
huge investments in railway development plans in India and Bangladesh. The region is also 
interconnected  by  both  main-line  and  deep-sea  container  and  feeder  ships  distributing 
containers  throughout  the  region  from  hub  ports.  Container  throughput  growth  has  been 
impressive for Bangladesh, India, and Sri Lanka. There are over 200 flights linking regional

destinations.  Regional  inland  waterways  exist  between  Bangladesh  and  India.  Bhutan  and 
India’s northeastern states are linked to the rest of India by the narrow, 27-kilometer-long Siliguri 
route referred to as the “chicken’s neck,” and use Kolkata and Haldia as their gateway ports. 
This important regional route illustrates two broad issues constraining regional connectivity in 
South Asia: the limited capacity of physical infrastructure and nonphysical barriers. 
 
6.  There are various constraints on regional connectivity in South Asia as identified in 
BTILS and SRMTS. The overall quality of road infrastructure requires improvement to the 
standard for articulated trucks. High axle-load trucks could then be used for more efficient trade. 
In rail transport, gauge difference is a major challenge for efficient international trade. Rail 
connectivity with landlocked countries would boost the trade of lower-value products. Regular 
container service networks would enhance the competitiveness of the railways. In maritime, 
draught constraints limit the accessibility of large ships. Operational efficiency and intermodal 
connectivity must also be improved. Main-line and deep-sea container ships, currently calling at 
Colombo, may change routes depending on the technology of vessels and the efficiency of 
various ports. In aviation, improvements are needed in airport capacity, cargo handling capacity, 
and intermodal connectivity. In trade facilitation, full utilization of information technology for 
automated customs clearance is required in parallel with overall customs modernization and 
reform. Border infrastructure also needs to be improved. 
 
7.  Inadequate coordination among transport subsectors and intermodal connectivity are 
principal factors constraining improvement in regional connectivity. For roads and railways, the 
last sections of links to border-access points are often left undeveloped because they are 
beyond their major networks and multiagency coordination is required. In aviation, possible 
rerouting may be explored to improve the efficiency of air transport. This, however, requires 
multiagency  coordination,  including  agencies  relating  to  defense  and  foreign  affairs. While 
solving constraints by mode, an optimal multimodal mix should be pursued to ensure the 
efficiency  of  economic  activities  and  energy  consumption,  which  also  requires  adequate 
coordination among transport subsectors and non-transport agencies. For the long term, the 
optimal multimodal mix should help mitigate climate change. 
 
8.  Countries with well-developed and integrated transport and communications systems 
tend to attract more foreign direct investment. Integrated transport systems improve access to 
subregional markets, making structural changes in their production capacities that can expand 
and diversify the basket of goods available for export. This is essential to transforming the 
smaller economies of South Asia. 
 
9.  The transport  and trade facilitation strategy for  South  Asia  will  support the goal  of 
regional development through cooperation by focusing on external regional and ultimately global 
linkages. In recent years, governments at the regional level have developed policy frameworks 
and  strategies  for  regional  connectivity  (BTILS)  and  identified  a  priority  regional  transport 
network (SRMTS). At the same time, national development plans have begun to reflect the 
importance of external and global linkages. Further integration of national transport systems 
with subregional systems is required, as identified by BTILS and SRMTS. The development of 
national transport projects of subregional importance is the first building block of this process. 
 
10.  SRMTS, BTILS, the Asian Highway network, and the Trans-Asian Railway network have 
identified key regional transport projects from the strategic perspective. As a result of these 
strategic perspectives, ADB has provided financing assistance to national projects with regional

3 
implications in Bhutan and Nepal.4 The progress and implementation of these projects have 
varied  across  countries,  depending  on  their  importance  from  the  perspective  of  in-country 
connectivity. Built on these strategic perspectives, the TA will identify critical sections or projects 
for prioritization to realize the economic impacts of such priority regional projects on each 
country and the region as a whole and prepare specific projects with engineering, social and 
environmental  studies,  prompting  governments,  ADB,  and  other  development  partners  to 
coordinate their investments in these regional transport projects. The TA will also address 
inadequate coordination among transport subsectors and intermodal connectivity. 
 
11.  The current regional cooperation operations business plan (2010–2012) continues to 
support  the  region  to  realize  its  full  economic  and  social-development  potential,  including 
enabling South Asia to integrate its cooperation initiatives with neighboring regions.5 To achieve 
this goal, it has five key operational objectives: (i) improving connectivity, (ii) facilitating trade 
and investment, (iii) developing regional tourism, (iv) facilitating energy cooperation, and (v) 
promoting private sector cooperation. The TA is required to prioritize and prepare projects for 
improving regional connectivity to promote regional cooperation and integration. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact of the TA is to promote regional cooperation and integration among South 
Asian countries through increased passenger and freight transport in the regional transport and 
distribution system. Major indicators include the increased volume of cross-border traffic above 
the average traffic growth rate of the country concerned, and increased industrial activities in 
project-influenced areas. The outcome of the TA is to promote investment in regional transport 
projects  in  South  Asian  countries.  Major  indicators  include  the  increased  number  and 
investment amount of regional transport projects. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA will comprise two components: (i) a regional transport sector study to produce a 
regional transport master plan prioritizing critical projects with future regional traffic flow, and (ii) 
prefeasibility  studies  for  high-priority  regional  projects  with  immediate  impacts  to  be 
demonstrated. The two components will be conducted in parallel and focus is on prefeasibility 
studies, comprising engineering, social, resettlement and environmental studies, so that actual 
implementation for immediate financing could be considered by ADB, development partners and 
governments. The TA consultants will review the extensive series of related reports compiled 
over the past decade, and consult with experts currently engaged under various regional TAs in 
South Asia, including those relating to trade aspects, to develop traffic scenarios. The TA will 
assess the studies and investment projects currently planned or underway in each country. It 
will field missions to all four countries to discuss transport and non-transport agencies relevant 
to regional transport connectivity. It will also set up a computerized database to be easily 
adjusted and used by each country for future planning and monitoring.

14.  For regional transport study, the key activities are: 
 
(i)  assessing the existing infrastructure and traffic conditions, and setting traffic and 
economic scenarios; 
(ii)  estimating  potential  traffic  growth  under  various  scenarios  and  the  costs  of 
regional projects; 
(iii)  assessing social, resettlement, and environmental impacts; 
(iv)  determining prioritization criteria; 
(v)  assessing economic impacts, including the distribution of costs and benefits for 
the region and for each affected country; 
(vi)  prioritizing projects; 
(vii)  setting up planning and monitoring systems; and 
(viii)  holding a regional conference to agree to the study. 
 
15.  For prefeasibility studies, the key activities are: 
 
(i)  determining high-priority projects for the study; 
(ii)  assessing project engineering, economic, financial sustainability, and safeguard 
studies; 
(iii)  assessing the institutions involved in regional transport cooperation; and 
(iv)  holding a regional conference to agree to prefeasibility studies. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA will cost $2,000,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $2,000,000 equivalent on a 
grant  basis:  $1,100,000  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV)  and 
$900,000 from the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund6 under the Regional Cooperation 
and Integration Financing Partnership Facility. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency. A regional TA secretariat, which will be headed by a 
regional  transport  focal  person,  will  be  established  in  ADB’s  South  Asia  Department.  The 
secretariat  will  facilitate  coordination  within  ADB’s  South  Asia  Department  and  ADB 
interdepartmental  meetings  during  implementation,  including  providing  technical  experts  to 
advise,  provide  guidance,  and  share  experiences  of  other  ADB  operations  in  regional 
cooperation  and  integration  such  as  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  and  the  Central  Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation. 
 
18.  A national interministerial working group or committee will be established in each country, 
headed  by  a  senior  government  official  and  composed  of  other  senior  officials  from  the 
ministries  concerned.  Each  working  group  or  committee  will  be  responsible  for  providing 
guidance on and support of the TA activities in its country and for ensuring coordination with 
ADB in the TA implementation. The focal agency will represent its country at multicountry 
regional  transport  conferences  to  discuss  the  regional  TA  study.  Each  working  group  or 
committee may designate a research coordinator from among research institutes in the country 
to provide technical and administrative support.

19.  The TA will be implemented over 18 months, beginning in March 2011 and ending in 
September 2012. It will be carried out by experts in transport planning, logistics and supply 
chain management, trade economics, traffic engineering, engineering in transport infrastructure, 
customs, the environment, social development, and resettlement. The input will be about 39 
person-months of international and about 48 person-months of national consulting. In addition to 
this team of consultants, about 6 person-months of individual international consultants will be 
engaged with expertise in regional transport cooperation to provide advisory services and as 
resource persons. Substantial works, e.g., the draft final report, should be completed within 10 
months of commencement; the remaining 8 months will be used to solicit and incorporate 
comments from governments. 
 
20.  ADB will hire consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Assignments will involve high-level policy discussions 
with multiple agencies and countries, which requires a certain level of innovation in project 
delivery. The quality- and cost-based selection (full technical proposal) should be adopted, with 
a  weight  of  technical  proposal  at  90%.  Administrative  support  will  also  be  provided  to 
governments for national working groups/committees and the use of national research centers 
as required. The terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. All equipment for the TA 
will be procured according to ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to 
time) and handed over to the relevant government upon TA completion. Disbursements under 
the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook 
(2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  Close coordination among South Asian countries is required to create common ground 
on project priority and preparation. Regional workshops and/or conferences will be held. For 
prefeasibility studies, affected persons and business communities will be consulted as required. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
22.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $2,000,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  Regional  Transport 
Development in South Asia.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Scope of Services 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will prioritize regional transport projects based on an 
economic assessment of these projects, and undertake a prefeasibility study for at least one 
priority project in each subsector. The study comprises two components: (i) a regional transport 
sector study, and (ii) a prefeasibility study of high-priority projects. Support for coordination will 
also be provided through the TA implementation. 
 
2.  During the TA implementation, the consultants will hold regional and national meetings 
as  well  as  workshops  and  conferences  to  advance  the  consultative  process  among  the 
countries in the region, build a consensus, and monitor the progress of the proposed TA. 
 
1.  Regional Transport Sector Study 
 
3.  The consultants will undertake a regional transport sector study, which will serve as a 
basis for the development of regional systems of transport over the long term. The study will 
indicate critical links that need to be established, the most suitable modalities for such linkages, 
the criteria for prioritization of system elements, the possible phasing of their development, 
financing options and possibilities, and the likely socioeconomic and environmental impacts. 
The study will be based on the findings and recommendations of existing regional studies, 
particularly  the  South  Asian  Association  for  Regional  Cooperation  (SAARC)  Regional 
Multimodal  Transport  Study  (SRMTS)  and  the  Bay  of  Bengal  Initiative  for  MultiSectoral 
Technical and Economic Cooperation (BIMSTEC ) Transport Infrastructure and Logistics Study 
(BTILS). While SRMTS, BTILS, the Asian Highway, and the Trans-Asia Railway provide certain 
routes, the study will also consider potential alternate routes, based on the latest progress of 
relevant projects. 
 
4.  A team of consultants will undertake the following tasks, in close coordination with 
ongoing Asian Development Bank (ADB) subregional studies: 
 
(i)  Assessing existing traffic and setting out scenarios for transport demand forecast, 
assuming  country-specific  development;  certain  trade  policies;  cross-border 
efficiency,  based  on  the  development  of  trade  practices;  and  cross-border 
operations in the region. Realistic scenarios will be set for at least three cases 
providing  low-,  medium-,  and  high-trade  volumes,  taking  into  account  global 
logistic chains.   
(ii)  Analyzing networks and forecasting traffic for each subsector (road, rail, air, port, 
and waterway), taking into account intermodal connectivity and the optimal and 
realistic modal mix, e.g., identifying the main transport network systems required 
to  link  production  with  other  economic  and  tourism  centers;  and  developing 
opportunities in the region, by utilizing existing data and studies, and conducting 
a traffic-data survey as required to supplement and update existing data. 
(iii)  Surveying transport infrastructure inventory for each subsector, utilizing existing 
data and studies, and conducting supplemental surveys as required, to estimate 
the preliminary development cost for required improvements of regional transport 
projects as a whole and for each country. 
(iv)  Assessing  social,  resettlement,  and  environmental  impacts,  and  identifying 
measures to mitigate major negative impacts as required.

(v)  Developing a set of prioritization criteria in consultation with governments and 
ADB, and utilizing them, highlighting contributions to regional cooperation with 
distributions to each country. 
(vi)  Undertaking  economic  assessments  for  each  project  to  estimate  the  rate  of 
return on investment for the region (economic internal rate of return as regional 
projects), with distributions to each country (economic internal rate of return as 
separate  national  projects),  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects  and  Handbook  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of 
Subregional Projects.1 
(vii)  Assessing the distribution of costs and benefits among countries, and, if there 
are substantial differences, providing a mechanism for how such imbalances, if 
any, can be adjusted.   
(viii)  Studying  financing  options,  including  possible  public–private  partnership 
schemes. 
(ix)  Prioritizing regional projects and identifying bottlenecks in each subsector for 
urgent,  medium-  and  long-term  development  (10  years),  and  identifying  the 
highest-priority regional transport projects for possible ADB financing. 
(x)  Preparing a computerized database that can be easily adjusted and used by 
each country for future planning and monitoring. 
 
5.  In addition to issues discussed in the BTILS, consultants will take into account the 
following:  
 
(i)  For roads, railways, and land ports, developing the institutional mechanism to 
ensure the development of access links to border points, taking into account 
multiagency coordination. 
(ii)  For  seaports,  the  need  for  strategic  and  coordinated  development  may  be 
determined by identifying the role of each port in the global logistics chain for 
efficient transport investment. 
(iii)  For aviation, the possible restructuring of air routing may be explored to improve 
the  efficiency  of  air  transport,  in  addition  to  regional  open  skies  and  safety 
aspects. 
 
  2.  Prefeasibility Study 
 
6.  Consultants will assess and prepare studies of regional transport projects, which will be 
identified as high priority with immediate impacts to be demonstrated. The studies, which will be 
selected in close consultation with the participating governments from a list of potential transport 
projects,  are  expected  to  provide  potential  projects  to  be  financed  by  ADB  and/or  other 
interested parties by the end of the proposed TA. Apart from the obvious benefits of advancing 
regional economic cooperation and of the attendant development impact, the positive signals 
that such quick results will convey should increase interest in and a commitment to furthering 
regional economic cooperation. 
 
7.  A team of consultants will undertake the prefeasibility study for priority regional transport 
projects,  including  engineering,  economic,  financial,  environment,  social,  and  resettlement 
studies. In addition, the prefeasibility study will highlight: (i) the justification of the proposed 
project as a priority within the subregional transport network, (ii) the contributions of the project

  3.  Coordination 
 
8.  Internationally recruited consultants will be engaged for a total of 6 person-months to: 
 
(i)  provide  technical  advice,  and  coordinate,  integrate,  and  synthesize  various 
studies to be undertaken under the TA; 
(ii)  assist  in  the  selection  of  priority  regional  transport  projects,  including  the 
establishment of selection criteria; 
(iii)  assist  in  the  planning  and  conduct  of  national  consultative  workshops  and 
regional conferences, including the preparation of a summary of the proceedings; 
(iv)  advise on various aspects of implementation of the proposed TA; 
(v)  study the institutional aspects of regional cooperation in transport in South Asia, 
including the institutional set-up of the overall sector and at the subsector level, 
such as a better approach to regional training program in aviation;   
(vi)  consolidate and fine-tune the database for countries; and 
(vii)  participate in consultation and monitoring missions. 
 
B.  Schedule and Staff Requirements 
 
9.  The consulting service will be completed in 18 months, from March 2011 to September 
2012. The consultant team will include (i) 39 person-months of international inputs, and (ii) 48 
person-months of national inputs from selected countries as in Table A3.1. Major tasks will be 
completed  in  10  months,  followed  by  solicitation  and  incorporation  of  comments  from 
governments. The consultant team is required to schedule the work program in such a manner.
